Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from Sam: “Hey, can you hop on a quick video call? I’m drowning in screws and these instructions make no sense.” I glanced at the clock—2:45 p.m. Only two hours left in the quarter, and I was still three sales short of my target. The office was tense, everyone dialing furiously, management pacing behind us, reminding us what was at stake. If I missed my quota, not only would I lose my bonus, but the whole team would face penalties. But Sam sounded desperate, and I remembered how he’d dropped everything to help me move last year. I stared at my headset, then at my phone, feeling the pressure from both sides. My friend needed me, but so did my job. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—be a reliable friend, or a responsible employee. I hesitated, torn, the seconds ticking by.
